Content: Reactive phosphorus of Lake Cedrino and Temo (SI001231 Sardinian Lake Ecosystems) in 2012

This dataset includes reactive phosphorus data taken in two research sites (Lake Cedrino and Temo) of the site Sardinian Lake Ecosystems as part of LTER Italy. Samples were collected as representative of each season during 2012. Data comprise measurements in the water column ad different depth from surface to the bottom.

The orthophosphate ion (PO43-) reacts with ammonium molybdate and antimony potassium tartrato under acidic conditions to form a complex. This complex is reduced with ascorbic acid to form a blue complex which absorbs light at 880 nm. The absorbance is proportional to the concentration of orthophosphate in the sample. In the point of maximum depth of the lake. Water samples are collected at different depths (surface, 1, 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10, 15, 20 and at intervals of 10 m to the bottom) with a Niskin bottle and placed in a dark cooler box and packed in ice at the time of collection seasonally

Silica reacts with molybdate reagent in acid media to form a yellow silicomolybdate complex. This complex is reduced by ascorbic acid to form the molybdate blue color. The color intensity is proportional to the silica concentration. In the point of maximum depth of the lake. Water samples are collected at different depths (surface, 1, 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10, 15, 20 and at intervals of 10 m to the bottom) with a Niskin bottle and placed in a dark cooler box and packed in ice at the time of collection seasonally

Dataset provides phytoplankton densities recorded in Lake Santo Parmense in 2012. Samples were collected by means of a Ruttner bottle at different depths over the water column at the point of maximum depth of the lake. Samples were fixed with Lugol's solution. An integrated sample was subsequently obtained by combining equal proportions of samples collected at various depths and phytoplankton were identified and counted with an inverted microscopeaccording to Utermöhl (1958).

Utermöhl H., 1958. Zur Vervollkommnung der quantitativen Phytoplankton-Methodik. Mitt. int. Ver. theor. angew. Limnol. 9: 1-38. Ruttner bottle Phytoplankton samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -1 m, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, -8 m, -12 m, -16 m, bottom. Samples were fixed with Lugol's solution. An integrated sample was subsequently obtained by combining equal proportions of samples collected at various depths. Phytoplankton were identified and counted with an inverted microscope according to Utermöhl (1958). Samples were collected monthly from May to October 2012. monthly

Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -1 m, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, -8 m, -12 m, -16 m, bottom. Samples were fixed with Lugol's solution. An integrated sample was subsequently obtained by combining equal proportions of samples collected at various depths. Phytoplankton were identified and counted with an inverted microscope according to Utermöhl (1958). Samples were collected monthly from May to October 2012. monthly

Samples were analysed according to Strickland and Parsons (1968).

Atmospheric deposition and Chemistry of precipitation and snow from _ Bucegi - Piatra Craiului LTER_EU_RO_002

Air quality data represents concentrations of O3, NO2 and NH3 measured during the period 15.05-15.10 (monthly exposure) of years 2011 and 2012 in 11 plots in Bucegi-Piatra Craiului LTER site. Atmospheric depositions were measured during the whole period (2011-2012) in 6 plots. The reported parameters are: pH (determined by potentiometry), conductivity (conductimetry), nitrite in NH4 and inNH3 (water ion-chromatography) and alkalinity (titrimetric determination)

Concept: Author / Originator World Wide Web Address

Content: Metadata date 2013-06-05 00:00:00 Dataset legal obligation reporting Council Directive 92/43/EEC of 21 May 1992 on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora;1992-05-21;publication

Air quality data represents concentrations of O3, NO2 and NH3 measured during the period 15.05-15.10 (monthly exposure) of years 2011 and 2012 in 11 plots in Bucegi-Piatra Craiului LTER site. The pollutants were monitored using Ogawa passive samplers (www.ogawausa.com). Chemical analysis of passive samplers was performed at ICAS Campulung Moldovenesc laboratory, using ion-chromatography for ozone determination and colorimetry for NO2 and NH3.Atmospheric depositions were measured during the whole period (2011-2012) in 6 plots. Precipitations were collected inside the forest (throughfall) using 8 collectors and in open field using 2 collectors. Soil solution was monitored in 2 plots, using the profile method, with collectors placed at 10, 20, 40 and 60 cm depth (2 replicates). The reported parameters are: pH (determined by potentiometry), conductivity (conductimetry), nitrite in NH4 and inNH3 (water ion-chromatography) and alkalinity (titrimetric determination). All chemical analysis were performed by ICAS Campulung Moldovenesc laboratory following the methodology described in ICP Forests Manual (http://www.icp-forests.org/pdf/FINAL_Depo.pdf; http://www.icp-forests.org/pdf/FINAL_SoilSol.pdf)

All chemical analysis were performed by ICAS Campulung Moldovenesc laboratory following the methodology described in ICP Forests Manual (http://www.icp-forests.org/pdf/FINAL_Depo.pdf; http://www.icp-forests.org/pdf/FINAL_SoilSol.pdf)

Dataset provides nitrate concentrations measured in Lake Santo Parmense in 2012. Water samples were collected by means of a Ruttner bottle at different depths over the whole water column at the point of maximum depth of the lake. Samples were analysed by means of the Ultraviolet Spectrophotometric Screening Method (Armstrong, 1963)

Dataset provides monthly precipitation data measured in 2012 at the Lagdei weather station, which is the closest weather station to Lake Santo Parmense and Lake Scuro Parmense (about 1 km from Lake Santo Parmense and 5 km from Lake Scuro Parmense). The weather station is managed by the the Environmental Protection Agency of the Emilia-Romagna region (ARPA Emilia-Romagna), which kindly provided data.

Dataset provides ammonium concentrations measured in Lake Scuro Parmense in 2012. Water samples for ammonium analysis were collected by means of a Ruttner bottle at different depths over the whole water column atthe point of maximum depth of the lake. Samples were analysed spectrophotometrically according to Koroleff (1970).

Koroleff F., 1970. Direct Determination of Ammonia in Natural Waters as Indophenol Blue. Information on techniques and methods for seawater analysis, Interlaboratory Report No. 3, I.C.E.S., Charlottenlund: 19–22. Ruttner bottle Water samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, bottom; Samples were kept refrigerated and transported to the laboratory where ammonium concentrations were determined spectrophotometrically following the Indophenol blue method (Koroleff, 1970). Sampling was carried out monthly from June to October 2012. monthly

Nitrite of Lake Cedrino and Temo (SI001231 Sardinian Lake Ecosystems) in 2012

This dataset includes nitrite data taken in two research sites (Lake Cedrino and Temo) of the site Sardinian Lake Ecosystems as part of LTER Italy. Samples were collected as representative of each season during 2012. Data comprise measurements in the water column ad different depth from surface to the bottom.

Nitrate is quantitatively reduced to nitrite by passage of the sample through a column containing copper coated cadmium. The nitrate (reduced nitrate plus original nitrite) is determined by diazotizing with sulfanilamide dihydrochloride. The resulting water soluble dye has a magenta color which is read at 520 nm. In the point of maximum depth of the lake. Water samples are collected at different depths (surface, 1, 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10, 15, 20 and at intervals of 10 m to the bottom) with a Niskin bottle and placed in a dark cooler box and packed in ice at the time of collection seasonally

Data set contains abiotic parameters of the Zingster Strom water column (upper 50 cm). This part of the site Darß-Zingst Bodden is situated between the innermost waterbodies and exhibits average salinity and nutrients. Data are sampled daily at 8:00. Data are given as monthly medians. The data of 2011 and 2012 are contributed to the EnvEurope project (action 5).

The given site contains some of the used methods as laboratory instructions to be downloaded as pdf. They were written for students paractical courses. The language of this material is German (only, so far). A station methods manual is under construction. Language will be English. Note, that nutrients are measured in a continuous flow analyser, not manually. Some methods are still missing (plankton microscopy). Some methods changed recently or will be modified soon. Any user has to ask for the exact information for a specific method and time range. salinity: WTW Cond 1970iwater temperature: mercury thermometerSecchi diskturbidity: Xion 500 photmeter, 5 cm cell lengthpH: Hach-Lange IntelliCell, HQ30doxygen: Hach-Lange LDO optode, HQ30d Water is sampled with a Rutner sampler from the upper 50 cm of the water column daily at 08:00 CET. Oxygen saturation is measured in a Karlsruher bottle within 5 min in the lab. Salinity, turbidity and pH are measured in 15-20°C warm samples. The sampling spot represents a very small spot of the area. However, the Zingster Strom is subject to in- and outflows of the neigbouring bodden basins. This brings a high variability of day-to-day data, but may expand the areal coverage/representation. daily

Precipitation was collected over longer periods (~monthly) using rainfall collectors and bulk samplers. Chemistry (pH, EC, chemical composition) of samples was analyzed in laboratory with standard methods (Analab Kft. www.analab.hu) Precipitation collectors: 1 above-canopy (25m) and 7 throughfall collector (1.2 m) with 0.2 m2 collecting area. Bulk samplers (25 l). Standard water chemistry analysis methods. Bulk samples were collected 6 times during 2012, covering the vegetation period from May to November. The over-canopy collector was set on the top of the site's own meteorological tower. Below-canopy collectors were randomly distributed in the 'B' subplot (50x50m) of the permanent 1 ha plot of the site. Results of all sampling dates were averaged on the basis of collectors' position (over- or below-canopy). monthly

Triplicated water samples fixed with formaldehyde (4% V/V) in situ. Ssp identification with inverted optical microscope with epifluorescence (Olympus IX50). Counting of individual phytoplankton cells after filtering 0.1 ml through black Isopore membrane filters GTBP with a 0.2 μm pore size and washing the cells with citrate buffer (pH 6). Each filter was examined for the autofluorescence of cell pigments at 1000X. The measurements were made under microscope according to the method described by Fry (FRY, J. C. 1990. Data on 9 permanent observation pine stands are presented. Investigations are carried out since the 1992. Presented data: dendrometric parameters, condition, defoliation, tree ring width series, FAR/LAI, primary productivity, dead wood, meteorology, soil and needle chemistry, graound vegetation.
Metadata date 2013-05-31 00:00:00 Dataset access and use constraints Principal:Research has granted a permission of type:Other restrictions according to rules defined in itellectual rights

Data on tree and stand parameters (mean diameter and height of trees, tree density, basal area and tree volume per hectare) as well as crown defoliation were available from the permanent observation stands. A three-stage sampling pattern was used for the collection of the field material: (i)                  sampling of the research stands; (ii)                sampling of the circular plots within each research stand; (iii)         sampling of the trees for more detailed measurements of tree crown parameters and tree ring analysis. Each pine stand included 12 circular sample plots distributed systematically in a grid system with on average 15-20 trees in each plot, i.e.; about 150-250 sample trees per stand. There, tree stem diameter was permanently measured and crown defoliation assessed for all sample trees annually. In addition three closest to the centre of sampling plot trees were sampled for measurement of crown parameters (height, diameter and length) and analysis of annual radial increment (tree ring width). Standard dendrochronological technique was used to assess tree growth rates. Radial growth was assessed by measuring the width of annual rings in stem cores. Each ring was measured to the closest 0.01 mm using an electronic transducer and binocular scope fixed over the moving stage. Based on the ring widths and measured diameter we computed stem basal area increment (BAI). For each of the POS a BAI chronology was computed by averaging the BAI for each year across all trees sampled at POS. Crown defoliation was assessed at the end of August. Forest monitoring methodology was employed to assess tree defoliation: healthy trees – (defoliation up to 10%); slightly damaged trees (defoliation ranging from 11 to 25%); moderately damaged trees (defoliation 26–60%); severely damaged trees (defoliation 61–99%); dead trees (defoliation 100%) (UN-ECE, 1994).  Instrument for tree dendrometric parameters measurement UN-ECE. Manual on methods and Criteria for Harmonised Sampling, Assessment, Monitoring and Analysis of the Effects of Air Pollution on Forests. ICP, 1994. annually

Habitat type was determined according to the Council Directive 92/43/EEC on the Conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora. The site is characterized as unmanaged, since it is protected by law as nature conservation area. Natural disturbances: grazing: visual observation of insect bursts and defoliation. droughts: calculation of monthly De Martonne aridity indices using monthly sum precipitation and monthly mean temperature data as follows: prec/(temp+10)*12. Months with Idx DM lower than 20 (semi arid or dry) were considered as dry periods. Weather data were measured by the site's own meteorological staition at 25m above ground: Hobo ProSeries RHandTemp sensor and Hobo Micro Station with rain gaugue (Onset Computer Corporation, Pocasset, USA) This dataset is considered to be representative of the whole 28 ha area of Sikfokut LTER site. Daily mean temperatures and sums of precipitation were converted to monthly data. continual

Vertical profiles of underwater photosynthetic active radiation (PAR) are collected on a monthly basis in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1). The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site.Data are used to characterize the light field and light extinction in the coastal Long Term Ecosystem Research station of the Gulf of Trieste, in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea and of the Mediterranean basin. General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

Vertical profiles of temperature are collected on a monthly basis in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1), using a CTD multiparametric probe. The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site. Data are used to characterize the temporal dynamic of hydrological properties in the coastal Long Term Ecosystem Research station of the Gulf of Trieste, in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea and of the Mediterranean basin. General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

Samples were analysed according to Strickland and Parsons (1968).

Data on forest structure, condition, increment ans well as LAI, Leaf and soil chemistry are presented. Data on 20 permanant observation pine stands are presented. Investigations are carried out since the 1986. Presented data: dendrometric parameters, condition, defoliation, tree ring width series, FAR/LAI, primary productivity, dead wood, meteorology, soil and needle chemistry

20 stands were located in the surroundings of Integrated monitoring stations (IMS) established there, and were selected according to stand maturity: 4 sapling stands (45–50 years), 4 middle aged stands (61–80 years), 4 premature stands (81–100 years), 3 mature stands (101– 120 years) and 5 over mature stands more than121 years). Data on tree and stand parameters (mean diameter and height of trees, tree density, basal area and tree volume per hectare) as well as crown defoliation were available from the permanent observation stands. A three-stage sampling pattern was used for the collection of the field material: (i)                  sampling of the research stands; (ii)                sampling of the circular plots within each research stand; (iii)         sampling of the trees for more detailed measurements of tree crown parameters and tree ring analysis. Each pine stand included 12 circular sample plots distributed systematically in a grid system with on average 15-20 trees in each plot, i.e.; about 150-250 sample trees per stand. There, tree stem diameter was permanently measured and crown defoliation assessed for all sample trees annually. In addition three closest to the centre of sampling plot trees were sampled for measurement of crown parameters (height, diameter and length) and analysis of annual radial increment (tree ring width). Standard dendrochronological technique was used to assess tree growth rates. Radial growth was assessed by measuring the width of annual rings in stem cores. Each ring was measured to the closest 0.01 mm using an electronic transducer and binocular scope fixed over the moving stage. Based on the ring widths and measured diameter we computed stem basal area increment (BAI). For each of the POS a BAI chronology was computed by averaging the BAI for each year across all trees sampled at POS. Crown defoliation was assessed at the end of August. Forest monitoring methodology was employed to assess tree defoliation: healthy trees – (defoliation up to 10%); slightly damaged trees (defoliation ranging from 11 to 25%); moderately damaged trees (defoliation 26–60%); severely damaged trees (defoliation 61–99%); dead trees (defoliation 100%) (UN-ECE, 1994).  Instruments for estimation of the tree dendromentric parameters UN-ECE. Manual on methods and Criteria for Harmonised Sampling, Assessment, Monitoring and Analysis of the Effects of Air Pollution on Forests. ICP, 1994. annually

Automatic measurement and logging of weather parameters. Hobo Temp/Rh sensors, Hobo Microstation with Rain gaugue and PPFD sensors (Onset Computer Corporation, Pocasset, USA), Millimet automatic meteorological station (Boreas Kft., Hungary) Weather data were collected on the top of the site's meteorological tower (25 m), above the forest canopy layer. The sampling interval was 10 min. Weather records were aggregated on monthly base. The following weather data were collected: Monthly mean, minimum and maximum air temperatures (2011-2012). ICP Forests The dataset is created according to the ICP Forests Ground Vegetation manual. The nomenclature follows the Flora Europaea (Tutin et al., 1968-1980; Tutin et al., 1993) for vascular plants and Frey et al. (1995) for bryophytes.   Procedures for data validation follow the GV manual of ICP Forests. The dataset is already validated by University of Camerino the Responsible Body for data validation. The sampling units are not contiguous; they are placed as far apart as possible within the Level II plot in order to minimize spatial correlation between the sampling units. All measures of the sampling units are taken according to the slope. To achieve a statistical representativeness, probability sampling methods are adopted (random, systematic, stratification). Location of sampling unit excludes major heterogeneities at any scale of sampling (boulders and cliffs, tracks and paths, fire places, streams and ponds, ditches and channels, peaty pools). Thus, terricolous plants growing on mineral and organic soil of the undisturbed forest floor are represented. seasonally

Biomass of vegetation and LAI of grasslands in Orgovány LTER (KISKUN LTER)

The aim of the yearly biomass and LAI measurements in the grasslands is to study the effect of weather to the plant production along a productivity gradient. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset.

Biomass and LAI in grasslands was measured by harvesting all herbs and plant material over a small parcel of 0.25 m2. In mown grassland, sampling was made right before mowing. Otherwise, the sampling was made approx.at the time of the maximum LAI. As much as possible, clipping was made right at the level of the ground. All plant material was dried at 60⁰C until constant weight.From the dried material three fractions were separated: (1) plant material which was dead in the time of clipping, (2) non-photosynthesising living material, and (3) photosynthesising material. Biomass was calculated by summing up the dry weight of all living material, and expressed in grams / m2. For LAI measurement, the photosynthesising material was separated into groups consisting parts of seemingly similar morphology, and therefore specific leaf area (SLA). Then, the groups are weighted, and subsamples of known weights are taken for area measurement, applying high resolution scanner. Calculation of SLA and LAI: The subsamples of known weight and area provide the SLA in m2 / grams for the morphology groups, and the total area of the groups can be calculated by multiplying their SLA and weight. Sum of the areas of the morphology groups divided by the area of sampling unit provides LAI in m2 / m2. The sample were taken in grasslands of Orgovány LTER site of KISKUN LTER. The data are considered to be representative for the grasslands of KISKUN LTER. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset. annually

The data are considered to be representative for the grasslands of KISKUN LTER. Discrete water samples for phosphate(P-PO4) analysis were collected at 0.5, 5, 10 and 15 meters in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1). The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site. Nitrite is measured colorimetrically after sample pre-filtration, using a segmented flow analyzer. Data are used to study biogeochemical nutrient cycles in the coastal Long Term Ecosystem Research station of the Gulf of Trieste, in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea and of the Mediterranean basin. Availability and partition of nitrogen in dissolved and particulate pools result from the concurrence of different forcing factors such as the general circulation, alternation between summer stratification and winter mixing, weather conditions, river discharge, diffuse and point-source continental inputs, sediment–water interactions and several biological processes. General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

IT_SI001137_20120719; Chemical Data of the water column in Lake Maggiore from 1981 to 2010

Dataset provides information about chemical data of the water column in Lake Maggiore from 1981 to 2010. In particular the data are on: Temperature, Conductivity, Alkalinity, Oxygen, PH, Total Phosphorus.

Different methods are used according to the parameter measured, temperature  and pH are mesaured during sampling with the autosampler; the other parameters are measured in the laboratory; Conductivity is referred to 20 °C; Total alkalinity determination is done with Gran's method; Dissolved oxygen is measured with Winkler's volumetric method; ; Spectrophotometry is used for Total Phosphorus after autoclave mineralization     Reversing termometer associated with sampling bottle, Conductometer in laboratory, , autosampler (Gran's method),  Titration, pHmeter, Spectrophotometer Measurements are performed at 4 depths (0, 5, 10 and 20 m of the water column) and values are calculated as weighted average. monthly

Health status of forests and above ground biomass in Bucegi - Piatra Craiului LTER_EU_RO_002

In 2011 and 2012, 3101 respectively 3125 trees were evaluated according with ICP Forest Manual in Bucegi - Piatra Craiului LTER site. For most species, the most suitable time for the assessment is mid- to late summer. Defoliation is defined as needle/leaf loss in the assessable crown as compared to a reference tree. Defoliation is assessed in 5% steps. These classes are 0, 5 ( more than0-5%), 10 ( more than5-10%) and so on. The uploaded data presents values in accordance with these criteria.

Vertical profiles of salinity are collected on a monthly basis in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1), using a CTD multiparametric probe. The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site. Data are used to characterize the temporal dynamic of hydrological properties in the coastal Long Term Ecosystem Research station of the Gulf of Trieste, in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea and of the Mediterranean basin. General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

Diversity, biomass and observed data of grasslands in Orgovány LTER (KISKUN LTER)

The dataset contains number of plant species, diversity (within habitat), number (and type) of layers, presence/absence (and type) of management, presence/absence (and type) of natural disturbances, aboveground biomass by indirect methods, presence/absence of groundwater table and presence/absence of susceptibility of the site to drought. Sampling plots are the same used for biomass and LAI measurements in the Orgovány LTER (KISKUN LTER) grassland. The aim of the yearly biomass and LAI measurements in the grasslands is to study the effect of weather to the plant production along a productivity gradient. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset.

Number of plant species: The aboveground biomass of vascular plants are removed from 0.5 x 0.5 m quadrats for biomass and LAI measurements. In mown grassland, sampling was made right before mowing. Otherwise, the sampling was made approx.at the time of the maximum LAI. As much as possible, clipping was made right at the level of the ground. All plant material was dried at 60⁰C until constant weight. After drying, the photosynthesizing vascular plant material seemingly living at time of cutting (i.e. the dry green material) are separated by species. The species samples are weighed separately at precision of 0.01 grams, the number of species counted. Within habitat diversity: Shannon'H is calculated from vascular plant species dried living biomass data. For one quadrat: m(i) is mass of i-th species, M is total mass, n is number of species, Shannon's H = -SUM(i=1 to n)[(m(i)/M)*log2(m(i)/M)] Number and type of layers: Visual observation. Presence and type of management: Visual observation. Presence of natural disturbances: Visual observation. Aboveground biomass by indirect methods: Spectroradiometry using CROPCSAN spectroradiometer before sampling for BIOMASS. Aboveground plant biomass measurement, see above. Calculation of NDVI for each measurements: (NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED); Application of linear regression between BIOMASS and NDVI data measured in the same quadrats. Presence of groundwater table: Expert decision. Quality of drought susceptibility: Expert decision. The sample were taken in grasslands of Orgovány LTER site of KISKUN LTER. The data are considered to be representative for the grasslands of KISKUN LTER. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset, the full biomass and LAI data are submitted in HU_SI001199_biomass_lai_20130508 dataset. annually

Dataset provides soluble reactive phosphorus (SRP) concentrations measured in Lake Santo Parmense in 2012. Water samples for SRP analysis were collected by means of a Ruttner bottle at different depths over the whole water column at the point of maximum depth of the lake. Samples were analysed spectrophotometrically according to Valderrama (1977).

Valderrama J.C., 1977. Methods used by the hydrographical department of the National Board of Fisheries. In Grasshof, K. (ed.), Report of the Baltic Intercalibration Workshop. Annex, Interim Commission for the Protection of the Environment of the Baltic Sea, Goteborg, Sweden: 13–40. Ruttner bottle Water samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -1 m, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, -8 m, -12 m, -16 m, bottom. Samples were kept refrigerated and transported to the laboratory, where soluble reactive phosphorus was determined spectrophotometrically following the method proposed by Valderrama (1977). Samples were collected monthly from May to October 2012. monthly

The soil of the site was classified in JAKUCS, P. (1985): Ecology of an oak forest in Hungary. Akadémiai Kiadó, Budapest, pp. 19–32. The original Hungarian classification was transormed to FAO WRB. Soil samples were analysed by an accredited agrochemical laboratory according to standard Hungarian procedures. The following parameters were measured: pH(H2O), soluble salts, upper plasticity limit, calcium-carbonate, humus, total phosporus, total inorganic nitrogen, K2O, C%, N%, C/N. Soil samples were analysed by accredited agrochemical laboratory of Mezogazdasagi Szakszolgaltato Kft. (Hodmezovasarhely, Hungary) Soil samples were taken from the upper 20 cm in May, July and November of 2012. Samplings represent 1 ha permanent plot of the LTER site. quarterly

Absorbed fraction of incoming PPFD was assessed indirectly by comparing PPFDs above and below the forest canopy. Hobo Microstations with PPFD sensors (Onset Computer Corporation, Pocasset, USA) 1-1 PPFD sensor was set above (25m, top of the meteorological tower) and below the forest canopy (2m height, 10m from the meteorological tower), respectively, both within the 'B' subplot of the 1 ha permanent plot of the LTER site. PPFD data were recorded with 10 min sampling frequency and transormed to daily sums. Radiation absorption was assessed by comparing monthly mean PPFDs above and below the canopy layer. continual

Suspended particulate matter and biomass in Zingster Strom 2011-2012

Data set contains characteristics of suspended particulate matter of the Zingster Strom water column (upper 50 cm). This part of the site Darß-Zingst Bodden is situated between the innermost waterbodies and exhibits average salinity and nutrients. Data are sampled daily at 8:00. Data are given as monthly medians. The data of 2011 and 2012 are contributed to the EnvEurope project (action 5).

The given site contains some of the used methods as laboratory instructions to be downloaded as pdf. They were written for students paractical courses. The language of this material is German (only, so far). A station methods manual is under construction. Language will be English. Note, that nutrients are measured in a continuous flow analyser, not manually. Some methods are still missing (plankton microscopy). Some methods changed recently or will be modified soon. Any user has to ask for the exact information for a specific method and time range. seston (suspended particulate matter): filtered onto GFF, dried overnight at 60°C, weightedchlorophyll a: filtered onto GFF, stored frozen, extracted at room temperature in the dark for 16-24 h in ethanol, photometricallyTN and TP: digested with Oxisolv (persulfate) in a lab microwave, neutralised and measured as nitrate and phosphate Water is sampled with a Rutner sampler from the upper 50 cm of the water column daily at 08:00 CET. TN, TP, POC are sampled only weekly. The sampling spot represents a very small spot of the area. However, the Zingster Strom is subject to in- and outflows of the neigbouring bodden basins. This brings a high variability of day-to-day data, but may expand the areal coverage/representation. daily

The given site contains some of the used methods as laboratory instructions to be downloaded as pdf. They were written for students practical courses. The language of this material is German (only, so far). A station methods manual is under construction. Language will be English. Note, that nutrients are measured in a continuous flow analyser, not manually. Some methods are still missing (plankton microscopy). Some methods changed recently or will be modified soon. Any user has to ask for the exact information for a specific method and time range. ammonium: indophenolblue formation, photometrically, fresh 0,45 mm filtrate, manuallyphosphate: molybdenum blue, photometrically, frozen 0,45 µm filtrate, continuous flow analysernitrite: formazan dye, photometrically, frozen 0,45 µm filtrate, continuous flow analysernitrate: formazan dye, reduction at a cadmium catalyser, photometrically as nitrite and nitrate, frozen 0,45 µm filtrate, continuous flow analyser, corrected for nitrite Water is sampled with a Rutner sampler from the upper 50 cm of the water column daily at 08:00 CET. 100 ml are filtered immediately through 0,45 µm cellulose acetate filters. Ammonium is incubated at once, the other sample is frozen for the 3 other nutrients. The sampling spot represents a very small spot of the area. However, the Zingster Strom is subject to in- and outflows of the neigbouring bodden basins. This brings a high variability of day-to-day data, but may expand the areal coverage/representation. daily

Dataset provides ammonium concentrations measured in Lake Santo Parmense in 2012. Water samples were collected by means of a Ruttner bottle at different depths over the whole water column at the point of maximum depth of the lake. Samples were analysed spectrophotometrically according to Koroleff (1970).

Koroleff F. 1970. Direct Determination of Ammonia in Natural Waters as Indophenol Blue. Information on techniques and methods for seawater analysis, Interlaboratory Report No. 3, I.C.E.S., Charlottenlund: 19–22. Ruttner bottle Water samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Ammonium of Lake Cedrino and Temo (SI001231 Sardinian Lake Ecosystems) in 2012

This dataset includes ammonium data taken in two research sites (Lake Cedrino and Temo) of the site Sardinian Lake Ecosystems as part of LTER Italy. Samples were collected as representative of each season during 2012. Data comprise measurements in the water column ad different depth from surface to the bottom.

When ammonia is heated with salicylate and hypochlorite in an alkaline phosphate buffer, an emerald green color is produced which is proportional to the ammonia concentration. The color is intensified by the addition of sodium nitroprusside. In the point of maximum depth of the lake. Water samples are collected at different depths (surface, 1, 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10, 15, 20 and at intervals of 10 m to the bottom) with a Niskin bottle and placed in a dark cooler box and packed in ice at the time of collection seasonally

Suspended particulate matter and biomass in the Darß-Zingst Bodden Chain 2011-2012

Data set contains characteristics of suspended particulate matter of 9 stations within the Darß-Zingst Bodden Chains water column (upper 50 cm). Data are sampled during monthly boat trips. Data are given as individual values. The data of 2011 and 2012 are contributed to the EnvEurope project (action 5).

The given site contains some of the used methods as laboratory instructions to be downloaded as pdf. They were written for students paractical courses. The language of this material is German (only, so far). A station methods manual is under construction. Language will be English. Note, that nutrients are measured in a continuous flow analyser, not manually. Some methods are still missing (plankton microscopy). Some methods changed recently or will be modified soon. Any user has to ask for the exact information for a specific method and time range. seston (suspended particulate matter): filtered onto GFF, dried overnight at 60°C, weightedchlorophyll a: filtered onto GFF, stored frozen, extracted at room temperature in the dark for 16-24 h in ethanol, photometricallyTN and TP: digested with Oxisolv (persulfate) in a lab microwave, neutralised and measured as nitrate and phosphate Water is sampled with a Rutner sampler from the upper 50 cm of the water column during monthly boat trips. Samples are transported cooled and in shadow. They are treated within 6 h the same day. The sampling spots represent a very small spot of the area. Mixing evens are just investigated to conclude on representative spots. monthly

Abiotic parameters in the Darß-Zingst Bodden Chain 2011-2012

Data set contains abiotic parameters of the Darß-Zingst Bodden Chain water column (upper 50 cm). 9 sites are sampled along a salinity (1-14 psu) and eutrophication gradient during monthly boat trips. All data are individual results.  The data of 2011 and 2012 are contributed to the EnvEurope project (action 5).

The given site contains some of the used methods as laboratory instructions to be downloaded as pdf. They were written for students paractical courses. The language of this material is German (only, so far). A station methods manual is under construction. Language will be English. Note, that nutrients are measured in a continuous flow analyser, not manually. Some methods are still missing (plankton microscopy). Some methods changed recently or will be modified soon. Any user has to ask for the exact information for a specific method and time range. salinity: WTW Cond 1970iwater temperature: mercury thermometerSecchi diskturbidity: Xion 500 photmeter, 5 cm cell lengthpH: Hach-Lange IntelliCell, HQ30doxygen: Hach-Lange LDO optode, HQ30d Water is sampled with a Rutner sampler from the upper 50 cm of the water column during monthly boat trips. Samples are transported in PE contained as cool as possible, in the shadow. All sampels are treated on the same day (mostly within 6 h). The sampling spots represent most likely the respective water body. However, newest measurements of mixing fronts point to incomplete mixing with the water basins and homgeneously mixed water within the strems and at the connection to the open Baltic. monthly

The given site contains some of the used methods as laboratory instructions to be downloaded as pdf. They were written for students practical courses. The language of this material is German (only, so far). A station methods manual is under construction. Language will be English. Note, that nutrients are measured in a continuous flow analyser, not manually. Some methods are still missing (plankton microscopy). Some methods changed recently or will be modified soon. Any user has to ask for the exact information for a specific method and time range. ammonium: indophenolblue formation, photometrically, fresh 0,45 mm filtrate, manuallyphosphate: molybdenum blue, photometrically, frozen 0,45 µm filtrate, continuous flow analysernitrite: formazan dye, photometrically, frozen 0,45 µm filtrate, continuous flow analysernitrate: formazan dye, reduction at a cadmium catalyser, photometrically as nitrite and nitrate, frozen 0,45 µm filtrate, continuous flow analyser, corrected for nitrite Water is sampled with a Rutner sampler from the upper 50 cm of the water during monthly boat trips. Samples are transported in PE containers, cool and shaded. Sampels are treted the same daily (mostly within 6 h). 100 ml are filtered immediately through 0,45 µm cellulose acetate filters. Ammonium is incubated at once, the other sample is frozen for the 3 other nutrients. The sampling spots represent a very small spot of the respective water basins. Water mixing is investigated now. monthly

Solar radiation, wind speed and direction are available, but are not ready yet (calculation from continuous measurements not ready).

Diversity and abundance of birds at TERENO sites (2001): Friedeburg, Greifenhagen, Schafstaedt, Wanzleben

The data are gathered within the TERENO (Terrestrial Environmental Observatories) long-term research programme involving several Helmholtz Association Centers in Germany (www.tereno.net).  TERENO aims to catalogue the longterm ecological, social and economic impact of global change at regional and landscape level. The biodiversity part of TERENO deals with monitoring and research on different organism groups: (1) Vascular plants (primary producers, overall biodiversity indicators), (2) Bees and Hoverflies (important pollinators; ecosystem service agents), (3) Butterflies (indicators for habitat quality, pollinators), (4) Birds (highly mobile, sensitive to landscape context, integrative at landscape scale).This dataset covers bird count data of 4x4 km landscapes in Saxony-Anhalt (Germany) dominated by agricultural use. All singing, calling and seen birds were registered according to the point counts method described by Bibby et al. (1992): Bird census techniques, Academic press, London.

Point count Point count Spatial design: 5 quadrats of 1km² arranged as checkerboard grid (4 visiting points in each quadrat, 20 visiting points for each site, 500m distance between each points); each point was visited 3 times (April, May, June) and all singing, calling or seen birds were registered within two circular bands of 50m and 250m radius: the maximum value for each species is considered for evaluation, as same individuals may have been registered more than once at the different times. Reference: Bibby et al. (1992): Bird census techniques, Academic press, London Very simple: Binoculars and compass only Sampling took place within the TERENO (Terrestrial Environmental Observatories; http://www.ufz.de/exploratories/index.php?en=21235) platform of the UFZ in saxony-Anhalt (Germany) Three times a year: within 1-30 April, 1-20 May, 21 May - 20 June (to be performed each third year)

Total Chlorophyll concentration of Lake Candia (Northern Italy), collected by CNR Institute of Ecosystem Study. This parameter is collected from 1986 until now at different depth (surface, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 m depth), and like an integrated water sample from 0 to 6 meters. The concentration is calculated according to the fluorimetric analysis and methanol extraction.

Meteorological data from _ Bucegi - Piatra Craiului LTER_EU_RO_002

This meteorological data are organised in three separate files. First one provides monthly precipitation and mean temperature from both meteorological stations (WMO compatible) placed in Bucegi-Piatra Craiului LTER site, the second one presents daily global radiation reaching the site, and the third one contains other main meteorological variables (wind speedanddirection, relative humidity).

Meteorological data from _ Bucegi - Piatra Craiului LTER_EU_RO_002

Vertical profiles of salinty are collected on a monthly basis in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1), using a CTD multiparametric probe. The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site. Data are used to characterize the temporal dynamic of hydrological properties in the coastal Long Term Ecosystem Research station of the Gulf of Trieste, in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea and of the Mediterranean basin. General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

Discrete water samples for dissolved oxygen analysis were collected at 0.5, 5, 10 and 15 meters in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1). Diversity and abundance of birds at TERENO sites (2012): Friedeburg, Greifenhagen, Schafstaedt, Wanzleben

The data are gathered within the TERENO (Terrestrial Environmental Observatories) long-term research programme involving several Helmholtz Association Centers in Germany (www.tereno.net).  TERENO aims to catalogue the longterm ecological, social and economic impact of global change at regional and landscape level. The biodiversity part of TERENO deals with monitoring and research on different organism groups: (1) Vascular plants (primary producers, overall biodiversity indicators), (2) Bees and Hoverflies (important pollinators; ecosystem service agents), (3) Butterflies (indicators for habitat quality, pollinators), (4) Birds (highly mobile, sensitive to landscape context, integrative at landscape scale).This dataset covers bird count data of 4x4 km landscapes in Saxony-Anhalt (Germany) dominated by agricultural use. All singing, calling and seen birds were registered according to the point counts method described by Bibby et al. (1992): Bird census techniques, Academic press, London.

Point count Point count Spatial design: 5 quadrats of 1km² arranged as checkerboard grid (4 visiting points in each quadrat, 20 visiting points for each site, 500m distance between each points); each point was visited 3 times (April, May, June) and all singing, calling or seen birds were registered within two circular bands of 50m and 250m radius: the maximum value for each species is considered for evaluation, as same individuals may have been registered more than once at the different times. Reference: Bibby et al. (1992): Bird census techniques, Academic press, London Very simple: Binoculars and compass only Sampling took place within the TERENO (Terrestrial Environmental Observatories; http://www.ufz.de/exploratories/index.php?en=21235) platform of the UFZ in saxony-Anhalt (Germany) Three times a year: within 1-30 April, 1-20 May, 21 May - 20 June (to be performed each third year)

Phytoplankton samples (100 ml) were fixed in Lugol’s solution and analyzed with Utermöhl’s technique (1958). Cell density was valuated analyzing subsamples of 5-10 ml of the fixed samples with an inverted microscope (Zeiss, Axiovert 10) at 200x and 400x magnifications in an adequate number of fields. Algal cells are concentrated by filtering a known volume of water through a membrane filter (47 mm, 5.0 µm pore size). The pigments are extracted from the concentrated algal sample in an aqueous solution of acetone. The chlorophyll a concentration is determined spectrophotometrically by measuring the absorbance (optical density - OD) of the extract at various wavelengths. The resulting absorbance measurements are then applied to a standard equation. In the point of maximum depth of the lake. Water samples are collected at different depths (surface, 1, 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10 and sometimes at 15 m depth) with a Niskin bottle and placed in a dark cooler box and packed in ice at the time of collection seasonally

Red Crayfish Consumer Biomass at Doñana LTSER Platform (2012)

The method consists in the provision of fishing gear (creels) in homogeneously distributed environments in the sampling station. The number of creels to provide depend on each sampling station. In general, it will have as many creels as possible at a distance of not less than 5 meters between them, with a maximum of five. For the selected stations that relate later, creels are arranged in three groups of three creels each, separate creels in at least five meters and groups in at least 50 meters. Each group of creels is considered one unit of effort.Creels should be type 'Shrimp' double death with mesh size of 4 mm., Sailing simple and approximate length of 3 m., 1:1 ratio between the candle and the body of the creel.Be placed on the ground, leaving part of the cod always above the water surface. The ring must be input, however, submerged as possible and at least the mouth must always be below the water surface. This arrangement minimizes the creelential effects on birds swimmers and decreases mortality of amphibians and reptiles caught in them.The review will take place between 12 and 24 hours of operation, and has remained at least one night on business.The provision on the ground will be supported on macoyas own vegetation or wetland or lake shore, using these elements to raise the cod and allow ventilation of creels.The withdrawal of the samples was made ​​by nasa, scoring in each case the crab specimens caught mention of the following parameters: a) total length, b) carapace width (of the first 20 copies),c) carapace length (of the first 20 copies), d) sex, e) sexual stage (I or II) and f) specific comments. To each creel is measured weight crabs assembly contained therein by the use of a Pesola. When the sample obtained more than 100 copies will bypass the steps a, b, c, d and e in the copies of the creel after the one containing the copy number 100, it being necessary to measure the remaining copies of the creel in which it is located .Log the data on catches of other specimens of any species, even without specific protocol for them.

Formal acknowledgement of the dataset providers
Formal acknowledgement of the dataset providers

Creel trapping and weighting of Procambarus clarkii individuals The method consists in the provision of fishing gear (creels) in homogeneously distributed environments in the sampling station. The number of creels to provide depend on each sampling station. In general, it will have as many creels as possible at a distance of not less than 5 meters between them, with a maximum of five. For the selected stations that relate later, creels are arranged in three groups of three creels each, separate creels in at least five meters and groups in at least 50 meters. Each group of creels is considered one unit of effort.Creels should be type 'Shrimp' double death with mesh size of 4 mm., Sailing simple and approximate length of 3 m., 1:1 ratio between the candle and the body of the creel.Be placed on the ground, leaving part of the cod always above the water surface. The ring must be input, however, submerged as possible and at least the mouth must always be below the water surface. This arrangement minimizes the creelential effects on birds swimmers and decreases mortality of amphibians and reptiles caught in them.The review will take place between 12 and 24 hours of operation, and has remained at least one night on business.The provision on the ground will be supported on macoyas own vegetation or wetland or lake shore, using these elements to raise the cod and allow ventilation of creels.The withdrawal of the samples was made ​​by nasa, scoring in each case the crab specimens caught mention of the following parameters: a) total length, b) carapace width (of the first 20 copies),c) carapace length (of the first 20 copies), d) sex, e) sexual stage (I or II) and f) specific comments. To each creel is measured weight crabs assembly contained therein by the use of a Pesola. When the sample obtained more than 100 copies will bypass the steps a, b, c, d and e in the copies of the creel after the one containing the copy number 100, it being necessary to measure the remaining copies of the creel in which it is located .Log the data on catches of other specimens of any species, even without specific protocol for them.

Nitrate and Phosphate concentrations at Doñana LTSER Platform (2011-2012)

Seasonal water sampling for estimation of Nitrates and Phosphates concentration at 4 sites representing the Doñana wetlands diversity (IDL1: Permanent phreatic lagoon, IDL12: Temporary phreatic lagoon, IDL28: Tributary river to the marshland and IDL46: Sesonally flooded marshland)

Nitrates and Phosphates concentration Rédacteur : S. L. Vérificateur : 8 . M. Approbateur : P. C. ALLlANCE METHOOS Parameter: Nitrates -Cadmium Application: Sea water System: FUTURA'MF) Range: 48 -161 1 L 3 -10 N03  I -DESCRIPTION OF THE METHOD: The nitrates are reduced into nitrites in a copper/cadmium column. Nitrites react with sulfanilamid in acid conditions to give a diazo compound. With N-(1-Naphthyl) ethylen diamin, it be comes a pink coloured complex. Colorimetric mesures are performed at 520/540 nm. Cadency : 60 to 80 samples 1hour. 11-REAGENTS PREPARATION : R1 Arnmonium chloride solution Ammonium chloride, NH4CI 10 9 Demineralised water, q.s. 1 000 mi Adjust the pH to 8.5 with ammonium hydroxide, NH40H. J R2 Colour reagent Sulfamilamid, C6 H8 N2 02 S 20 9 Concentrated phosphoric acid, H3P04 85 % 200 mi N-(1-Naphthyl) ethylen diamin dihydrochlorid, C12 H14 N2, 2HCI 0.5 9 Brij-35 (ALLlANCE T21-0110-05) 1 mi Demineralised water, q.s. 2000 mi Add 200 mi H3P04 to 1 500 mi of D.water. Dissolve 20 9 sulfamilamid . Meat if necessary. 0.5 9 Complete up to 2000 mi with D.water. Add 1 mi of 8rij¬Conservatían : 1 month at 4°C and protected from Iight. The cadmium-copper column must be used carefully. The system is run on reagents without the column. Once all reagents are pumped in the analytical circuit, the column is introduced in the circuit without introducing an air buble. At the end af the day, the column is first deconnected and the analytical circuit is then washed. Thus, the calumn remains always in the ammonium chloride solution. Standards preparation Solution 1 000 mg 1I N03 Potassium nitrate, KN03 1.63 9 Demineralised water , q.s. 1 000 mi Dissolve 1.63 9 of potassium nitrate in demineralised water. Add 1 mi of chloroform, CHCI3. Dilute up to 1 000 mi with demineralised water. Stabilitv /Conservatíon : 1 month at 4oC and protected from light. Working standard solution : Dilute stock solution in a about 39 gil of Na CI solution or in sea-water without NH4. Made standards according to the range. Sampler solution : NaCI about 39 gil solution I -DESCRIPTION OF THE METHOD: The ammonium molybdate reacts with the orthophosphates in acid condition to form the phosphomolybdic acid. It is reduced in 'molybdene blue' by ascorbic acid. The reaction is catalysed by potassium antimony oxide tartrate. Optical density is measured at the wavelength of 880 nm. -REAGENTS COMPOSITION : Sulfuric acid, about 6 N Sulfuric acid concentrated 95-97 %, H2S04 85 mi O.water, q.s. 500 mi Oissolve 85 mi of concentrated sulfuri9 cid in 200 mi O.water. Cool, adjust to 500 mi with O.water. Ammonium hepta olybdate 4 % Ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate, (NH4)6 M07 024, 4H20 8 9 O.water, q.s. 200 mi Stabilitv I Conservation : about 3 weeks at 4°C in an amber plastic container. J2Potassium antimony-(III) oxide tartrate 0.3 % Potassium antimony-(III) tartrate hemihYdrate(0,5 H20) 0.3 9 -150 mi ammonium heptamolybdate solution 4 % -50 mi potassium antimony oxide tartrate solution 0.3 % -10 mi diluant solution (reagent 3) Stabilitv I Conservation : about 3 weeks at 4 °C. R2 -Ascorbic acid solution Ascorbic acid, C6H806 4.5 9 O.water, q.s. 250 mi Oissolve 4.5 9 of ascorbic acid in 200 mI of O.water. Adjust to 250 mi with O.water. Stabilitvl Conservation : about 3 weeks at 4°C in an amber plastic container. R3-SOS Sg/L Oissolve 5 9 dodecylsulfate, sodium salt in 1 000 mi of distilled water. http://www.globalw.com/products/6820.html

Secondary producers: Fish Biomass at Doñana LTSER Platform (2012)

To achieve the objectives of this monitoring themselves used traps using light mesh Anguilera shrimp and, in order to obtain a wider range of size in fish catches.Are placed pots anguileras 2 to 5 depending on the dimensions of the station, the technical criterion and if the depth of the station permits, since by design require between 20 and 30 cm minimum depth for proper installation . Pots are preferably installed with a minimum of 15 meters apart. The deaths of pots point to the shore, and in the streams and creeks with current input to death is oriented counter to facilitate the entry of fish. It must ensure that traps are not completely sunk in the water to prevent drowning of other wildlife that can get caught in the trap.Also placed five shrimp pots of light, near-shore and far between around 10 meters, with the deaths to the center of the lagoon, from ingress completely covered by water.After about 24 hours, their extraction, pouring its contents into bowls or baskets with water, which is separated from the individuals counting them and weighing them by species.

Canopy trees were assessed in the LTER permanent core hectare in 2012. Abundance was assessed in the whole hectare using tree inventory of the LTER site. Canopy projection of trees was measured according to the ICP forest manual in the 50x50m subplot of the LTER core hectare (subplot 'A'). Shrub layer was assessed in the 50x50m subplot of the LTER core hectare (subplot 'A'), divided into 144 4x4m quadrates. Coverage was measured in 2007. Abundance was measured in 2012. Data on low (1m height) shrubs were processed separately. Herb layer was assessed in the 50x50m subplot of the LTER core hectare (subplot 'A'), divided into 144 4x4m quadrates. no instruments were used All vegetation assessments were done in the permanent representative hectare of Sikfokut LTER site which has been used since 1972 for similar purposes. Canopy trees were assessed by Ilona Mészáros and Viktor Oláh. Data on shrub layer was provided by Imre Kárász and Tamás Misik. Data on herb layer was provided by Mária Papp. irregular

Vascular Plant Coverage at Doñana LTSER Platform (2011-2012)

Annual vascular plant percent cover measured per species along 3 15m long transects inside 15x15m2 plots. 21 plots are placed in the dominant shrubland communities in Doñana Biological Reserve inside the Doñana LTSER Platform. Abundance may directly be estimated from percent cover. Species list is indicated listcode field.

Ammonium concentrations from the Gulf of Naples for Enveurope A5

Ammonium concentrations are provided from 10 depths (0 to 70 m)  from the LTER- Marechiara Station in the Gulf of Naples on 4 seasons, 2012. The four data were chosen as to represent differen phases in the seasonal cycle of plankton in the Gulf of Naples

Biomass of plant species of Orgovány LTER grasslands (KISKUN LTER)

The aim of the yearly biomass measurements in the grasslands is to study the effect of weather to the plant production along a productivity gradient. Aboveground living plant biomass data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The total aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data  are submitted in HU_SI001199_lai_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset.
Miklós Kertész MTA Centre for Ecological Research kertesz.miklos@okologia.mta.hu

Biomass in grasslands was measured by harvesting all herbs and plant material over a small parcel of 0.25 m2. In mown grassland, sampling was made right before mowing. Otherwise, the sampling was made approx.at the time of the maximum LAI. As much as possible, clipping was made right at the level of the ground. All plant material was dried at 60⁰C until constant weight.From the dried material three fractions were separated: (1) plant material which was dead in the time of clipping, (2) non-photosynthesising living material, and (3) photosynthesising material.Biomass species was calculated by summing up the dry weight of all living material belong to a species, and expressed in grams / m2. The sample were taken in grasslands of Orgovány LTER site of KISKUN LTER. The data are considered to be representative for the grasslands of KISKUN LTER. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset. annually

Biomass in grasslands was measured by harvesting all herbs and plant material over a small parcel of 0.25 m2. In mown grassland, sampling was made right before mowing. Otherwise, the sampling was made approx.at the time of the maximum LAI. As much as possible, clipping was made right at the level of the ground. All plant material was dried at 60⁰C until constant weight.From the dried material three fractions were separated: (1) plant material which was dead in the time of clipping, (2) non-photosynthesising living material, and (3) photosynthesising material.Biomass species was calculated by summing up the dry weight of all living material belong to a species, and expressed in grams / m2. The sample were taken in grasslands of Orgovány LTER site of KISKUN LTER. The data are considered to be representative for the grasslands of KISKUN LTER. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset. annually

EUNIS habitat types of biomass and LAI of samples of Orgovány LTER grasslands (KISKUN LTER)

The dataset contains the EUNIS habitat types of the sampling plots of the Orgovány LTER (KISKUN LTER) grassland biomass and LAI measurements. The aim of the yearly biomass and LAI measurements in the grasslands is to study the effect of weather to the plant production along a productivity gradient. Aboveground living plant biomass data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The total aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data  are submitted in HU_SI001199_lai_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the abovegroung biomass data of plant species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset.

Count of breeding colonies Counting of apparently occupied nests (AON) in tree nesting colonies is performed during the reproduction season by walking through the entire colony. An AON is a nest that is in use and sufficiently finished to hold one or more eggs of a breeding pair (BP). Counts are made when the maximum numbers of nests are occupied. If the nests were counted several times within the same season, the maximum number was considered. Each colony was fully counted annually

Water Sample for determination of seven fresh-water parameters of Srebarna Lake, Bulgaria

These data are seven freshwater parameters of Srebarna Lake. They are: water depth (m) of the lake, pH, conductivity, transperance Secchi (m), the amount of NO2, the amount of PO4 (mg/l) and the amount of Chlorophil a (mg/l). They were taken in May, August and November 2012 and these are data for spring, summer and winter season.

Phenology of dominant cover in the lowlands of Northeast Germany_2012

The dataset contains detailed data on land use within a landscape in the lowlands of Northeast Germany. You may find data on: crop species lists, crop frequencies, coverage data for the crops and total weed flora. The coverage data is correlated with total biomass and NPP. More detailed data on land management is available upon request.

The data are for 2 lakes in Danube Delta SI000709: Rosu ( 45° 3'14.80'N 29°34'30.84'E) and Baclanesti ( 45°14'53.86'N 29° 7'44.22'E). Monthly data from 1975 to 1994 for Rosu and from 1982 to 1993 for Baclanesti. The lakes are tipical shallow floodplain lakes, their level being highly dependent of the Danube discharge. Variable list: CP,Deptht, NH4N, NO3N, Ntot, O2D, pH, PO4, Ptot, S_org, SDT, SI, Temp (water).

Band census Transect is conducted at constant speed (10-20 km/h) during the morning low tide. This allow higher visibility (sunlight coming from the back). Stops were made when necessary (counting or identification). Wind speed (6 categories from calm to gale), wind direction, sky conditions (6 categories from sunny to rainy), sea conditions (6 categories from calm to very rough) and human use of the beach were noted together with bird counts binocular, telescope, 4x4 car Transect is conducted monthly between days 10 and 20 looking for the best morning tide. The about 25km transect was divided into three sections according to easily recognizable reference points. monthly

Litterfall collection by litter traps. Destructive sampling for aboveground biomass estimations of Q. petraea, Q. cerris and Acer campestre. Direct measurement of cut trees and separation of stem, branch and leaf biomasses. Allometry equations and tree inventory data (DBH) for estimation of total aboveground biomass of Quercus species. Litter traps for litter production. Destructive harvesting of trees for biomass measurements. Litterfall was assessed in 2012 using 25 litter traps representing the permanent hectare of the site, with 5.11 m2 total area and was transformed to kg/ha. Destructive samplings (3-3 individuals of Q. petraea, Q. cerris, Acer campestre) were performed within the LTER site, ~300 m from the 1 ha permanent plot. Tree inventory (DBH) of the 1 ha permanent plot was used for estimating aboveground biomass of Q. petraea and Q. cerris tree-by-tree and was summed up to kg/ha. irregular

Destructive samplings (3-3 individuals of Q. petraea, Q. cerris, Acer campestre) were performed within the LTER site, ~300 m from the 1 ha permanent plot. Tree inventory (DBH) of the 1 ha permanent plot was used for estimating aboveground biomass of Q. petraea and Q. cerris tree-by-tree and was summed up to kg/ha. irregular

Diversity and abundance of bees at TERENO sites (2010, 2011): Friedeburg, Greifenhagen, Schafstaedt, Wanzleben

The data are gathered within the TERENO (Terrestrial Environmental Observatories) long-term research programme involving several Helmholtz Association Centers in Germany (www.tereno.net).  TERENO aims to catalogue the longterm ecological, social and economic impact of global change at regional and landscape level. The biodiversity part of TERENO deals with monitoring and research on different organism groups: (1) Vascular plants (primary producers, overall biodiversity indicators), (2) Bees and Hoverflies (important pollinators; ecosystem service agents), (3) Butterflies (indicators for habitat quality, pollinators), (4) Birds (highly mobile, sensitive to landscape context, integrative at landscape scale).This dataset covers data about bees trapped within 4x4 km landscapes in Saxony-Anhalt (Germany) dominated by agricultural use. The trapping is done with combined flight traps (combination of yellow pan trap and transparent perspexes) placed at ecotones (transition zone between arable fields and semi-natural habitats) in May-June and August-September each year.

Combined flight traps Combined flight traps One trap / km² is placed at the border (ecotone) between semi-natural habitat and arable field (16 traps / site of 4x4 km). Traps consist of a yellow funnel (diameter: 25 cm) and two crossed perspex windows on top of the funnel. Trapped insects will fall in the funnel which is filled with water containing a preservative (Parmetol K 40; 0.5%). Traps are installed with a wooden frame at a height of about one m above ground. Operating schedule (emptying interval 14 days): Start at week 2–7 after full bloom of Taraxacum officinale (phenological indicator), usually in our region end of April or beginning of May; 4x emptying until end of June, then stop for 6 weeks and start again until end of September. Insects are sorted in the laboratory and sent to a specialist for determination. Frequency: yearly Yellow funnels, perspexes and wooden frames (trap material needs to be organized individually) Sampling took place within the TERENO (Terrestrial Environmental Observatories; http://www.ufz.de/exploratories/index.php?en=21235) platform of the UFZ in saxony-Anhalt (Germany) Yearly in May-June and August-September

LAI was assessed by indirect optical method using LAI-2000 instrument. Crown transparency and defoliation was assessed only for Q. petraea and Q. cerris trees according to the ICP Forest Manual. Stand-level mean starting and finishing days of leaf expansion and leaf shedding were determined indirectly by above- and below-canopy positioned PPFD sensors. LAI measuements: LiCor LAI-2000 intrument. Crown health status: visual observation, ICP Forest manual. Leaf expansion and leaf shedding: Hobo Micro Station with PPFD sensor (Onset Computer Corporation, Pocasset, USA) LAI-measurement was done along 10x10m sampling grid in the LTER site's 1 ha permanent plot in August 2012. As a total 81 sampling points were used, each measured in triplicate. All measurements were averaged to calculate mean LAI in 2012. Crown transparency and defoliation were assessed according to the ICP Forest Manual for all Quercus petraea and Q. cerris trees in the 'A' subplot (50x50m) of the LTER site's 1 ha permanent plot. Tree-by-tree assesment was done for all Q. petraea (59 ind.) and Q. cerris (13 ind.) trees of the subplot. Starting and finishing days of leaf exansion and leaf sheding were determined comparing daily sum of above- and below-canopy PPFD. Above-canopy PPFD was measured on the top of the site's own meteorological tower at 25m. Below-canopy PPFD sensor was set ~10m from the meteorological tower at 2m. Both sensors was set to 10 min sampling interval. For characterizing actual canopy status mean PPFDbelow/PPFDabove between DOYs 0-70 was considered as 'no canopy' status and PPFDbelow/PPFDabove between DOYs 150-250 was considered as 'full canopy' status. Reaching one of the above values was considered as starting or finishing of leaf exansion or leaf sheding, respectively. continual

Sikfokut LTER (Hungary) - aboveground net primary production 2011-2012 - EnvEurope A5

This dataset provides data about annual net primary production in the Síkfőkút LTER site (Hungary). Annual dry mass increment of canopy Quercus petraea and Q. cerris trees in 2011 and 2012 was assessed by tree ring and allometry data and corrected with tree mortality. Total litterfall in 2012 provides information on renewable biomass flux.

Analysis of annual tree increment by tree rings and calculation of dry weight change by allometry equations. Assessment of total litter production by litter traps. Tree rings: increment borer, digital scanner, ImageJ image analyses software. Litterfall: litter traps. Stand-level biomass increment was assessed by tree ring analyses. In 2011 130 Q. petraea and 99 Q. cerris samples were analyzed. In 2012 19-19 Q. petraea and Q. cerris samples were analyzed. All samples were collected in the permanent 1 hectare plot of the LTER site. Mean tree ring widths were used in allometry equations to calculate aboveground biomass change tree-by-tree and sum up to stand level using tree inventory of the site. Yearly increments were corrected by tree mortality data. Litterfall was assessed in 2012 using 25 litter traps representing the permanent hectare of the site, with 5.11 m2 total area and transformed to kg/ha. annually

Time-constrained de visu sampling of macrophytes percent cover per species Every water body is sampled during 15' starting from the shore to the deepest point. Macrophyte species are recorded and relative abundance is de visu assigned according to the following criteria:1 Species present in the sample by just one individual2 Percent cover less than 5%3 Percent cover more than5% and 25% and 50%Sampling period strictly depends on presence of water in the water bodies and is selected according to vegetative activity. Usually this corresponds to 2 seasonal samplings.

Macrophytes (relative abundance) at Doñana LTSER Platform (2012)

The data set provides information about the relationship between abiotic and biotic environments on the ecosystem scale whereas the extensity is correlated by the intensity of effective factors of structural and functional change. Available data comprise element cycling and water relationships on the one hand and the dynamics of effective concentrations mainly in the soil solution. Supplementary data are values for characterizing ecosystem structures and the related element pools as well as climate.
Millennium Ecosystem Assessment (MA). 2005. Ecosystems and Human Well-Being: Synthesis. Island Press, Washington

Sikfokut LTER (Hungary) - vascular plant species list - EnvEurope A5

This dataset contains the vascular plant species list of Sikfokut LTER site (Hungary).The list was composed of the results of a Multisite Experiment in 2007 and 2008, tree and shrub inventory in 2012, and herb layer assessment in 2012, respectively.Tree layer was assessed by Mészáros Ilona.Shrub layer was assessed by Misik Tamás and Kárász Imre.Herb layer was assessed by Papp Mária.

Vascular plants' species list was composed using results of a Multisite Experiment (MSE) in summer in 2007 and 2008, and tree and shrub inventory of the site's 1 ha permanent plot in 2012, respectively. Herb layer was assessed using 20 0.5x2m rectangular plots. Permanent vegetation plots. Most vegetation assessments were done in the 1 ha permanent plot of Sikfokut LTER site which has been used since 1972 for similar purposes. Canopy trees were assessed by Ilona Mészáros and Viktor Oláh. Data on shrub layer was provided by Imre Kárász and Tamás Misik. Data on herb layer was provided by Mária Papp. Further species were added to the list according to the species list composed during a Multisite Experiment in 2007-2008. This experiment was conducted within the borders of the site, ~300 m from the permanent 1 ha plot and used 20 0.5x1m plots. continual

Total phosphorus of Lake Cedrino and Temo (SI001231 Sardinian Lake Ecosystems) in 2012

This dataset includes total phosphorus data taken in two research sites (Lake Cedrino and Temo) of the site Sardinian Lake Ecosystems as part of LTER Italy. Samples were collected as representative of each season during 2012. Data comprise measurements in the water column ad different depth from surface to the bottom.

Samples are digested in an autoclave for 30 minutes at 121 °C with ammonium persulfate and sulfuric acid to convert all phosphorus to orthophosphate. The orthophosphate is then analyzed using the ascorbic acid procedure. In the point of maximum depth of the lake. Water samples are collected at different depths (surface, 1, 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10, 15, 20 and at intervals of 10 m to the bottom) with a Niskin bottle and placed in a dark cooler box and packed in ice at the time of collection seasonally

Dataset provides electric conductivity at 20°C measured in Lake Santo Parmense in 2012. Water samples were collected by means of a Ruttner bottle at different depths over the whole water column at the point of maximum depth of the lake. Conductivity was measured by means of a conductivity meter.

Discrete water samples for chlorophyll-a analysis were collected at 0.5, 5, 10 and 15 meters in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1). The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site.The overall aim of Long Term Ecosystem Research in the coastal area of the Gulf of Trieste, in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea and of the Mediterranean basin is to gain a better understanding of the temporal dynamics of phytoplankton bloom evolution, with particular focus on the response to natural and man – induced environmental changes.General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

Fluorimetric determination  Fluorimetric determination after particulate sample concentration by vacuum filtration and extraction in 90% acetone according to Holm – Hansen et al. (1965) and Lorenzen and Jeffrey (1980). Samples were filtered on Whatmann GF/F filters (diameter 47 mm, nominal porosity 0.7 μm) which were stored frozen (-20°C) until laboratory analysis. In order to assess precision and accuracy of measurements, on a regular basis, analytical and field precision measurements are carried out, based on the analysis of replicate samples and, with the aim of testing the accuracy, the laboratory participates to international intercalibration tests (QUASIMEME). The time series station C1 ( Latitude 45°42'2.99'N Longitude 13°42'36.00'E), located in the Gulf of Trieste in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea, is part of the Adriatic Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) site . It is a shallow coastal station (17 m depth) located at 0.2 Km from the coast, at the outer border of the Natural Marine Reserve of Miramare , Trieste. continual
